definitions.definition: a round object used for throwing, hitting or kicking in games and sports

examples.text: a golf/tennis/bowling/soccer ball
to **hit/throw/kick/catch a ball**
He kicked the ball into the net.
Bounce the ball and try and hit it over the net.
The kids were playing with a bat and ball in the park.
The ball bounced off down the road.
Oh no! He's dropped the ball.
She chased the ball all over the pitch.
The ball flew over the bar into the sea of Middlesbrough fans.
The ball hit me on the head.
The ball hit the wall and rolled along the road.
The catcher missed the ball.
The fielders try to retrieve the ball quickly and return it to the bowler.
The kids love to kick a ball against my wall.
He's an excellent ball handler.
His ball control was excellent.

definitions.definition: a round object or a thing that has been formed into a round shape

examples.text: The sun was a huge ball of fire low on the horizon.
a ball of yarn/string
The little girl curled into a ball in her mother's arms.
Some animals roll themselves into a ball for protection.
He screwed the letter up into a tight ball.

definitions.definition: a kick, hit or throw of the ball in some sports

examples.text: He sent over a high ball.
He pounced on a loose ball and scored.
That's a great ball from Kane.

definitions.definition: a throw by the pitcher that is outside the strike zone (= the area between the batter's upper arms and knees)
the part below the big toe or the thumb
a testicle
a large formal party with dancing

examples.text: She met him at the ball.
We're organizing a charity ball.
We're going to a masked ball.
They're holding a charity ball at the end of the month.
They've hired a 10-piece band for the summer ball.
You shall go to the ball, Cinderella!

definitions.definition: a problem that prevents you from doing what you would like to do

examples.text: The responsibility was a ball and chain around my ankle.

definitions.definition: it is your/somebody’s responsibility to take action next

examples.text: They've offered me the job, so the ball's in my court now.

definitions.definition: a person who is full of energy and enthusiasm
to take responsibility for getting something done

examples.text: My co-worker was sick, so I had to carry the ball.

definitions.definition: to make a mistake and cause something that you are responsible for to fail

examples.text: Let’s not drop the ball on this.

definitions.definition: to make something start happening; to make sure that something continues to happen
to enjoy yourself a lot
to be capable of doing a job very well; to be intelligent
to continue to give your attention to what is most important
to be aware of and understand what is happening and be able to react quickly

examples.text: The new publicity manager is really on the ball.

definitions.definition: to develop an idea or plan that already exists

examples.text: It's up to the private sector to take the ball and run with it.
The mainstream media will pick up the ball and run with it.
a challenge to other universities to pick up the ball and run with it

definitions.definition: to play with a ball

examples.text: Chris was in the park playing ball with the kids.

definitions.definition: to be willing to work with other people in a helpful way, especially so that somebody can get what they want

examples.text: We contacted the airline about a refund but they wouldn’t play ball.

definitions.definition: the whole thing; everything

examples.text: I panicked, I cried—the whole ball of wax.

wordOrigin: noun senses 1 to 6 Middle English: from Old Norse bǫllr, of Germanic origin. noun sense 7 early 17th cent.: from French bal ‘a dance’, from late Latin ballare ‘to dance’; related to Greek ballizein ‘to dance’ (also ballein ‘to throw’).
